WASHINGTON Congress on Wednesday overwhelmingly rejected President Barack Obama's veto of legislation allowing relatives of the victims of the Sept. 11 attacks to sue Saudi Arabia

column3: just four months before it ends.The House of Representatives voted 348-77 against the veto

But this time almost all his strongest Democratic supporters in Congress joined Republicans to oppose him in one of their last actions before leaving Washington to campaign for the Nov. 8 election.""Overriding a presidential veto is something we don't take lightly

column1: 1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-cuba-idUSKCN11Z2XT	Clinton says Trump may have violated U.S. law on Cuba	"
CHICAGO U.S. Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton said on Thursday that Republican opponent Donald Trump may have violated U.S. law
column2: following a news report that one of his companies attempted to do business in Cuba.Newsweek said on Thursday that a hotel and casino company controlled by Trump secretly conducted business with Cuba that was illegal under U.S. sanctions in force during Fidel Castro's presidency of the Communist-ruled island.(See the Newsweek article: bit.ly/2dmKH3e) ""Today we learned about his efforts to do business in Cuba which appear to violate U.S. law
column3: certainly flout American foreign policy
column4: and he has consistently misled people in responding to questions about whether he was attempting to do business in Cuba
column5: Clinton told reporters on her campaign plane.Clinton and Trump are in a close race ahead of the Nov. 8 presidential election.

column1: The Trump campaign did not immediately respond to a Reuters request for comment.Newsweek
column2: citing interviews with former Trump executives
column3: internal company records and court filings
column4: said the Trump company spent at least $68
column5: 000 for a 1998 trip to Cuba at a time when any corporate expenditure in the Caribbean country was prohibited without U.S. government approval.

column1: The Trump company did not spend the money directly
column2: but funneled the cash for the Cuba trip through an American consulting firm
column3: Newsweek said.Newsweek cited a former Trump executive as saying the goal of the Cuba trip was to give Trump's company a foothold should Washington loosen or lift the restrictions under the U.S. trade embargo.

column1: The former executive said Trump had participated in discussions about the Cuba trip and knew it had taken place
column2: according to Newsweek.""The efforts that Trump is making to get into the Cuba market
column3: putting his business interests ahead of the laws of the United States ... shows that he puts his personal and business interests ahead of the laws and the values and the policies of the United States of America
column4: Clinton said. (Reporting by Amanda Becker; Writing by Eric Beech; Editing by Mohammad Zargham and Peter Cooney)"

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-tacos-idUSKCN11Z2YP	Houston taco trucks register voters as Latinos flex political muscle	"
By Terry Wade
| HOUSTON

HOUSTON Taco trucks in Houston have begun doubling as voter registration sites as Latinos in Texas flex their political muscle before the Nov. 8 presidential election in a state that has long symbolized Mexican immigration to the United States.Riffing on widely ridiculed comments by Marco Gutierrez
column2: a supporter of Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump
column3: that without action on immigration reform
column4: ""you're going to have taco trucks on every corner
column5: the non-partisan civic group Mi Familia Vota is driving the effort to reach first-time voters.""We Latinos have been the group with the most growth in Texas
column6: but this hasn't translated into the political sphere
column7: said Houston coordinator Carlos Zamora. ""We want to build political capital.""Although Texas is a Republican stronghold
column8: demographics in the Lone Star State are seen shifting in favor of Democrats with the steady increase in Hispanic voters
column9: who have historically favored the party. In the 2012 election
column10: Latinos nationally voted for Democratic President Barack Obama over Republican Mitt Romney by 71 percent to 27 percent
column11: according to exit polls.The Pew Research Center estimated this year that 39 percent of Texans were Hispanic and that about 4.8 million Latinos were eligible to vote in the state.

column1: Historically
column2: there has been a voter registration gap. In 2012
column3: about 2.6 million Latinos were registered to vote in Texas
column4: according to the U.S. Census Bureau.In 2012
column5: Romney beat Obama in Texas by about 16 points. In this year's campaign
column6: Trump
column7: whose hardline approach to illegal immigration has alarmed many Hispanics
column8: leads Democrat Hillary Clinton in the state by about 8 points
column9: according to fivethirtyeight.com's average of polls.

column1: Mi Familia Vota did not say how many people it hoped to register in Texas. It said that in the first few days of the campaign
column2: it often had to restock registration brochures at the trucks.At Tacos Tierra Caliente
column3: one of eight taco trucks participating in the registration drive in Houston
column4: posters urging customers to vote hung next to the menu of meat stuffings painted on the side of the truck advertising barbacoa
column5: lengua and pollo.At the metal counter where they pay
column6: customers can fill out  voter registration cards that require no postage when mailed. The group plans to expand its campaign to other taco trucks across the country's fourth most populous city.

column1: (Fixes spelling of group's name
column2: paragraphs two and eight.) (Reporting by Terry Wade; Editing by Peter Cooney)"

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-usatoday-trump-idUSKCN12002F	Do not vote for 'demagogue' Trump
column2: USA Today tells its readers	"

column1: WASHINGTON Branding Donald Trump a ""dangerous demagogue
column2: USA Today on Thursday urged its readers not to vote for the Republican presidential candidate
column3: but added that it was not endorsing his Democratic rival Hillary Clinton either.The national newspaper said in an editorial that it had never taken sides in U.S. presidential elections in its 34-year history
column4: but was abandoning the practice because the New York real estate developer was unfit for the presidency.It went on to list and expand on eight reasons for its stance
column5: including: ""He is ill-equipped to be commander in chief
column6: ""He traffics in prejudice
column7: and ""He's a serial liar.""""Trump's foreign policy pronouncements typically range from uninformed to incoherent

column1: In an opinion piece on the USA Today website
column2: Trump's running mate Mike Pence wrote that the New York businessman was ""thoughtful
column3: compassionate and steady... I know he is ready to lead the United States as our next president and commander in chief.""Trump and Clinton are locked in a close race for the Nov. 8 election. A majority of Americans say Clinton won their first presidential debate on Monday
column4: according to a Reuters/Ipsos national tracking poll.

column1: USA Today
column2: published by Gannett Co Inc
column3: said its editorial board was divided on Clinton
column4: and some of the reservations about the former secretary of state centered on her ""sense of entitlement
column5: her lack of candor and her extreme carelessness in handling classified information.""

column1: Urging voters to stay true to their convictions
column2: USA Today said: ""Whatever you do
column3: however
column4: resist the siren song of a dangerous demagogue. By all means vote
column5: just not for Donald Trump."" (Reporting by Mohammad Zargham; Editing by Bill Rigby)"

column1: 4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-sept11-lawsuits-analysis-idUSKCN11Z326	Suing governments over terror no sure thing despite U.S. September 11 law	"
By Mica Rosenberg
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Families of Sept. 11 victims and others who may seek to sue foreign governments accused of supporting terrorism in the United States still face significant legal hurdles
column2: despite a boost from passage of a law allowing such cases to proceed. The new Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act
column3: or JASTA
column4: grants an exception to the legal principle of sovereign immunity in cases of terrorism on U.S. soil. Passage of the law over a presidential veto could allow relatives and survivors of the Sept. 11
column5: 2001 attacks to move forward with a case they filed more than a decade ago against Saudi Arabia in New York federal court.Still
column6: it will be hard to prove a foreign nation is responsible for acts of terrorism
column7: said attorneys and professors with expertise in international law
column8: who expected drawn-out legal wrangling.""We may find that at the end of the day
column10: that the link is not sufficiently established even for Saudi Arabia
column12: a law professor at Duke University. The law says plaintiffs must show the foreign state ""knowingly or recklessly provided material support or resources"" to designated terrorist groups
column13: not that the countries were simply negligent or looked the other way. Congress on Wednesday overwhelming voted to pass the law
column14: overturning President Barack Obama's veto. Before the law
column15: American victims of terrorist acts could only sue countries designated by the U.S. State Department as state-sponsors of terrorism
column18: any country can be sued if there are allegations of support for known terrorists that carry out attacks on U.S. soil. Existing tort law requires plaintiffs to prove that support played a ""substantial factor"" in the victims' injuries
column20: said Jimmy Gurule an expert in international criminal law at the University of Notre Dame.   This could be challenging in the Sept. 11 case since an independent commission on the 2001 attacks did not find sufficient evidence of Saudi involvement. Al-Qaeda claimed responsibility for the attacks and most of the 19 hijackers were Saudi nationals.

column1: We have a high degree of confidence we can meet that burden. The Saudis think we can't
column2: said Jack Quinn
column3: co-counsel for more than 2
column4: 000 family members of Sept. 11 victims. The families sued Saudi Arabia in 2003
column5: seeking to hold the country responsible. The proceedings have been stalled on the question of Saudi Arabia's immunityQuinn said the plaintiffs will now ask the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals to reconsider the issue in light of the new law. If the court says the case can move forward
column6: both sides will use discovery to seek documents and take depositions of witnesses and experts. ""We will next attempt to complete the development of evidence and find out what the truth is and on the basis of that
column7: let the chips fall as they may

column1: LONG BATTLE AHEAD
But even under the new law
column2: the White House can still request a court to halt this and other potential lawsuits.The law allows a court to put a proceeding against a foreign state on hold if the United States says it ""is engaged in good faith discussions"" with the country to resolve the claims. The stay provision and other changes were added to address concerns raised by the White House
column3: Saudi Arabia and companies like General Electric and Dow Chemical Co.

column1: Obama is likely to request such a stay
column2: said Bradley.Stephen Vladeck of the University of Texas School of Law
column3: said this revision and others injected uncertainty into the law and could result in litigation aimed at clarifying the bill's language.""The next step in this is either a whole bunch of lawsuits being placed on indefinite hold or a whole bunch of litigation to figure out the meaning of all these obstacles that Congress snuck back into the bill at the last minute
column4: said Vladeck.Even with the revisions
column5: detractors of the new law worried that it could inspire other countries to retaliate by enacting their own statutes that could drag the United States or U.S. companies into court. Some U.S. lawmakers said Congress may revisit the law to narrow it further. Ultimately
column6: though
column7: if the victims of terrorist acts win a court  judgment against a foreign government
column8: other cases have shown that collecting damages can be a slog.A Reuters analysis last year found that in the 10 years following the Sept. 11 attacks
column9: the number of lawsuits filed under the U.S. Anti-Terrorism Act and similar laws more than tripled compared to the decade before with plaintiffs winning billions of dollars worth of judgments in U.S. courts. But judgments awarded against organizations or governments are often unenforceable and even when there are assets that can be claimed in the United States
column10: their value often falls short of the award. (reut.rs/2dexDdV) (Reporting by Mica Rosenberg; Editing by Noeleen Walder and David Gregorio)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-security-clearance-idUSKCN11Z2TM	U.S. to open new vetting agency for 'secret' security clearances	"
By Mark Hosenball
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON The U.S. government will open the doors next week to a new agency
column2: with stronger data protections
column3: meant to shorten by many weeks the time it takes to vet government workers seeking ""secret"" and ""top secret"" security clearances.The National Background Investigations Bureau will be headed by Charles Phalen
column4: who has worked as a security executive at the CIA
column5: the FBI and defense contractor Northrop Grumman
column6: officials said on Thursday on a conference call with reporters.The bureau will replace an Office of Personnel Management (OPM) clearance system that was hit by hackers who stole potentially sensitive personal data on as many as 22 million people
column7: including government employees and job applicants.Phalen and OPM Director Beth Cobert said a top priority for the bureau will be shortening delays in the clearance process
column8: which can hold up the hiring of government employees for months.

column1: Cobert said that OPM figures show on average the time required to complete an investigation for a ""secret"" level security clearance is now 120 days; for a ""top secret clearance
column2: it is 170 days on average.""These timelines are well too long
column3: Phelan acknowledged.

column1: Cobert said the new agency's goal would be to reduce the time for completing a ""secret"" clearance to 40 days and to cut the time for a ""top secret"" investigation to 80 days.Officials said that individual government agencies
column2: rather than the new central investigations bureau
column3: would be responsible for social media checks of security clearance applicants.

column1: Officials said that the new bureau would still depend on outside contractors
column2: especially for hiring field investigators. The new agency will employ 2
column3: 500 government workers and 6
column4: 000 contract employees
column5: officials said. (Editing by Kevin Drawbaugh and Sandra Maler)"

column1: 6	http://reuters.com/article/us-kansas-voterid-idUSKCN11Z2PU	Kansas
column2: ACLU reach temporary agreement on voter ID	"

column1: The Kansas Secretary of State and the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) have reached a temporary agreement over the state's voter registration laws
column2: keeping Kansas' chief elections officer from a contempt of court hearing
column3: according to court documents filed on Thursday.The deal between Secretary of State Kris Kobach and the ACLU comes six weeks before the U.S. presidential election.The two sides have been at odds over a Kansas law requiring people to prove American citizenship if they want to register to vote while applying for a driver's license. Critics say this requirement disenfranchises voters
column4: especially minorities.The deal will allow people who registered at motor vehicle offices or with a federal form without providing citizenship documents to vote in the Nov. 8 election with a standard ballot
column5: rather than be forced to use a provisional one
column6: the ACLU and Kobach said in a status report filed on Thursday.Kobach will also clarify his office's website to help voters find information more easily
column7: according to the report filed to U.S. District Judge Julie Robinson. Robinson had ordered Kobach
column9: to explain by Thursday why he should not be held in contempt for failing to obey a federal order issued in May.

column1: That order required him to register people who applied to vote at motor vehicle offices or with a federal form without proof of citizenship.Robinson canceled the contempt hearing scheduled for Friday
column2: according to her own court filing
column3: citing the ACLU and Kobach's agreement.

column1: Our case is ongoing
column2: but this interim agreement is a critical victory for Kansans who want to vote in the November election. It is a shame that voters had to fight so hard to get Kris Kobach to do his job
column3: ACLU attorney Orion Danjuma said in a statement.Kobach said he was pleased an agreement had been reached
column4: but criticized the ACLU. ""The ACLU's argument was weak at best. However
column5: at this point the preparations for the November 8
column7: general election must proceed with rules established to ensure the efficient administration of the election

column1: Kansas' law
column2: among the strictest voter identification statutes in the country
column3: is defended by Republicans who say the rules are meant to prevent voter fraud. On Tuesday
column4: a Kansas state judge issued a separate ruling extending voting rights through the Nov. 8 election of about 17
column5: 500 people who registered to vote at motor vehicle offices.  (Reporting by Timothy Mclaughlin in Chicago; Editing by Matthew Lewis)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-poll-idUSKCN11Y2VB	Majority of Americans say Clinton won first debate against Trump: Reuters/Ipsos poll	"
By Chris Kahn
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK A majority of Americans say Democrat Hillary Clinton won Monday night's presidential debate
column2: but her performance doesn't appear to have immediately boosted her support among likely voters
column3: according to a Reuters/Ipsos national tracking poll released on Wednesday.The online poll
column4: which gathered responses from more than 2
column5: 000 people on Tuesday
column6: found 56 percent of American adults felt that Clinton did a better job than Trump in the first of their three televised debates
column7: compared with 26 percent who felt that Trump did better.Of those who thought Clinton emerged the victor
column8: 85 percent were Democrats and 22 percent were Republicans.

column1: U.S. presidential debates have historically been seen as a crucial test of candidates' poise and policies. Monday's was watched by a record 84 million viewers and was billed as a rare prime-time opportunity for two unpopular candidates to convince millions of undecided voters to back them.Afterward
column2: both candidates claimed victory.""""Every single online poll had me winning
column3: Trump said at a campaign stop in Council Bluffs
column4: Iowa on Wednesday. ""You sit back and you hear how well she did in the debate. I don't think she did well at all.""Clinton campaign spokesman Jesse Ferguson said the Democrat clearly won the debate as Trump ""was unprepared
column5: became unhinged and was incoherent throughout.""

column1: Among those who are expected to take part in the Nov. 8 general election
column2: 34 percent said they felt that the debate changed their view of Clinton in a positive way
column3: compared with 19 percent who said the same of Trump. DELAYED REACTION

column1: Some 31 percent of likely voters said the debate improved Clinton's chances of winning the White House
column2: while 16 percent said the debate benefited Trump.Even so
column3: Clinton's performance seemed to have little impact on her support among America's likely voters. The poll showed 42 percent supported Clinton while 38 percent supported Trump. Over the past few weeks Clinton has maintained a lead of between 4 and 6 points over Trump.Narrowing the focus to likely voters who watched the debate
column4: Clinton led Trump 44 percent to 39 percent.One possible reason for the lack of movement in her support is that it usually takes several days to measure the full impact of a single event
column5: like a debate
column6: said Donald Green
column7: a political scientist at Columbia University.

column1: The Reuters/Ipsos poll is conducted every day in English in all 50 states. Monday's sample of 2
column2: 036 American adults included 1
column3: 336 people who were considered to be likely voters from their voting record
column4: registration status and stated intention to vote in the election. Among those likely voters
column6: 026 said they watched some portion of the debate on live TV
column7: online or in media clips that were circulated after the debate.The poll has a credibility interval
column9: of 3 percentage points for the entire sample and the sample of likely voters. It has a credibility interval of 4 percentage points for the likely voters who watched the debate.National opinion polls have differed this year in how they measure support for Clinton and Trump. Some polls
column11: try to include only likely voters
column12: while others include all registered voters. The Reuters/Ipsos tracking poll gathers responses every day and reports results twice a week
column13: so it often detects trends in sentiment before most other polls.Polling aggregators
column14: which calculate averages of major polls
column15: have shown that Clinton's lead over Trump has been shrinking this month to about 2 percentage points. (Reporting by Chris Kahn
column16: editing by Richard Valdmanis and Ross Colvin)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-wallstreet-idUSKCN11Z2QQ	If elected
column2: Clinton under pressure to appoint tough Wall Street sheriffs	"

column1: By Amanda Becker
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Democratic Party progressives intent on reining in Wall Street are pushing Hillary Clinton to choose people to head the Treasury
column2: SEC and other agencies who will crack down on big banks if she wins the White House on Nov. 8.""Do they have a proven track record of challenging corporate power?"" asked Adam Green of the Progressive Change Campaign Committee
column3: a grassroots group aligned with U.S. Senator Elizabeth Warren
column4: the party's liberal firebrand.In meetings with Clinton's team
column5: progressive groups are urging that she break sharply with the centrist
column6: pro-business bent of some of the economic leaders who served her husband
column8: and President Barack Obama.Big U.S. banks are voicing concern about both Clinton and Donald Trump
column9: her Republican rival who has accused corporate America of buying influence in Washington.RASKIN A FAVORITE

column1: Among Democratic progressives
column2: a favorite for Treasury secretary is Sarah Bloom Raskin
column3: now deputy Treasury secretary and a backer of strict enforcement of the Volcker Rule that prohibits banks from making some types of speculative investments.""I view proprietary trading as an activity of low or no real economic value that should not be part of any banking model that has an implicit government backstop

column5: then a Federal Reserve governor
column6: said in a 2012 speech.Democratic activists
column7: who believe Obama did not go far enough at the height of the 2007-2009 financial crisis to punish bankers and tighten regulation

column2: not just institutions.SANDBERG
column3: BRAINARD

column1: Some Democratic activists are wary of two potential  Treasury candidates - Sheryl Sandberg
column2: Facebook's chief operating officer
column3: and Federal Reserve Governor Lael Brainard - because of links to the Bill Clinton and Obama administrations.Sandberg was chief of staff to Treasury Secretary Larry Summers in Bill Clinton's administration and Brainard was a top lieutenant to Timothy Geithner
column4: Obama's first Treasury secretary.

column3: Brian Fallon

column6: a commissioner on the Securities and Exchange Commission
column8: a former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund and co-author of a book warning of the dangers posed by big financial institutions

column11: for a senior administration role because of his reputation as a tough regulator when he headed the Commodity Futures Trading Commission in the Obama administration.

Jeff Hauser
column2: director of the Revolving Door Project at the Center for Economic and Policy Research
column3: said progressives have a ""broad feeling of regret"" that they did not exert more pressure on Obama to name officials committed to bold financial regulatory reforms.""It wasn't so much that progressives lost

column6: who would have a big microphone in any potential fight over U.S. Senate confirmation of nominees
column7: in a speech last week at the Center for American Progress

column12: and a twiddling of thumbs until it's time for the next swing through the revolving door
column13: serving government then going back to the very same industries they regulate

column16: for at least 120 administration jobs. Their potential candidates include state attorneys general who have taken on for-profit colleges and handled large mortgage settlements. (Reporting by Amanda Becker; Editing by Caren Bohan and Howard Goller)"
